title: Mpox and People with HIV

cleaned_text: and HIV: What's the Connection? Mpox is a disease caused by infection with the mpox virus. It can spread through close, personal, often skin-to-skin contact with someone who has mpox. While anyone can get mpox, CDC [research](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7136a1.htm) shows that about 40% of people diagnosed with mpox in the United States also have HIV. Also, people with compromised immunity—like people with untreated HIV—may experience more severe illness or even death. In fact, a CDC [study](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/72/wr/mm7215a5.htm?s_cid=mm7215a5_w) shows there were 38 mpox-associated deaths in the U.S. between May 10, 2022, and March 7, 2023. Nearly all with complete data on HIV infection were HIV-positive. And among the 24 with HIV and available data, all had advanced HIV. New cases of mpox have been reported in the United States [this spring](https://emergency.cdc.gov/han/2023/han00490.asp). It's important to know about how mpox spreads, how to protect yourself and others, and how to treat it if you get it. Watch the videos below to get the facts. Learn About the Mpox Vaccine Demetre Daskalakis, MD, MPH, Director, Division of HIV Prevention, National Center for HIV/AIDS, Viral Hepatitis, STD, and TB Prevention at CDC and White House National Mpox Response Deputy Coordinator, answers your top mpox questions. MORE VIDEOS - CLICK BELOW Please download and share these videos on your social media channels. Get the Facts About Mpox and HIV Looking for more information about mpox? It's important to separate myths from facts. Visit [CDC's mpox site](https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/monkeypox/index.html) for the latest information about mpox symptoms, how it spreads, prevention, vaccines, treatment, and more. Read [CDC's FAQ about mpox and HIV](https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/monkeypox/prevention/hiv.html). Fact sheets: [Get Healthy Ready for Vaccination](https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/mpox/your-health/vaccines/infections.html) [Mpox [Preventing Spread Patient's Guide to [Find more CDC resources here, including mpox resources in other languages](https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/monkeypox/resources/index.html) Also, view HHS' fact sheet, [HHS Provides Resources on Ways Communities Can Stay Protected from Mpox in Advance of Summer Months](https://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2023/05/18/fact-sheet-hhs-provides-resources-ways-communities-can-stay-protected-mpox.html) (May 2023). Isn't Mpox Over? The mpox national public health emergency ended on January 31, 2023, but that doesn't mean the virus is completely gone. Chicago reported a new cluster of mpox cases this spring. Vaccination is an important tool in preventing the spread of mpox. The vaccine may still protect against severe illness, hospitalization, and death. Get vaccinated with both doses of the vaccine, if it is [recommended](https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/mpox/vaccines/index.html) for you. Also, there continue to be populations experiencing mpox vaccination [disparities](https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/monkeypox/health-departments/vaccine-equity-pilot.html), such as Black/African American and Hispanic/Latino gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men. Read the [Mpox Equity Toolkit](https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/monkeypox/resources/toolkits/vaccine-equity.html) to learn how you can be involved in efforts to reach populations most affected by mpox.
